Module phpjavabridge
Package api.syntaxerror.phpjavabridge

Class Packet

java.lang.Object
api.syntaxerror.phpjavabridge.Packet
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Closeable, java.lang.AutoCloseable
public class Packet
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Closeable
PHP-Java-Bridge provides a TCP- or UDP-based connection between PHP (Client) and Java (Server)

licensed under the Apache License 2.0:

Permissions:

License: https://github.com/Synt4xErr0r4/PHP-Java-Bridge/blob/master/LICENSE
GitHub Repository: https://github.com/Synt4xErr0r4/PHP-Java-Bridge/
Wiki: https://github.com/Synt4xErr0r4/PHP-Java-Bridge/wiki
JavaDocs (for /src/java): https://github.com/Synt4xErr0r4/PHP-Java-Bridge/blob/master/javadoc/
A Packet is used to send and receive data.
Currently, there are 14 differen data types supported:
Available Data Types
ID Name Read method Write method
#0 boolean readBoolean() writeBoolean(boolean)
#1 byte readByte() writeByte(byte)
#2 unsigned byte readUnsignedByte() writeUnsignedByte(int)
#3 short readShort() writeShort(short)
#4 unsigned short readUnsignedShort() writeUnsignedShort(int)
#5 int readInt() writeInt(int)
#6 unsigned int readUnsignedInt() writeUnsignedInt(long)
#7 long readLong() writeLong(long)
#8 float readFloat() writeFloat(float)
#9 double readDouble() writeDouble(double)
#10 String (UTF-8) readStringUTF8() writeStringUTF8(String)
#11 String (ASCII, optimized) readStringASCII() writeStringASCII(String)
#12 String (C) readStringC() writeStringC(String)
#13 byte[] readByteArray() writeByteArray(byte[])
Version:
1.0
Author:
SyntaxError404, 2020

    Instantiates a new Packet

  • Method Summary

    Modifier and Type Method Description
    void close()
    deletes all the data in the Packet and disables read and write access
    int getPacketID()  
    boolean isLittleEndian()  
    boolean readBoolean()
    in theory a boolean is just a single bit:

    Space required (in bytes): 1
    byte readByte()
    range: -128 to 127

    Space required (in bytes): 1
    byte[] readByteArray()
    Stores an arbitrary amount of bytes Space required (in bytes): 4+n
    double readDouble()
    range: (2 - 2^(-52)) * (-2)^1023 ≈ -1.798E+308 to (2 - 2^(-52)) * 2^1023 ≈ 1.798E+308

    Space required (in bytes): 8

    Note: see readFloat() for information about precision
    Note: this might not work on machines whose internal double-size is not 64 bit
    float readFloat()
    range: (2 - 2^(-23)) * (-2)^127 ≈ -3.403E+38 ≈ 1.401E-45 to (2 - 2^(-23)) * 2^127 ≈ 3.403E+38

    Space required (in bytes): 4

    Note: due to floats being not 100% precise, calculations like 8 - 6.4 are actually not 1.6 as you might except, but 1.5999... You can even try this in Java:

    float a = 8 - 6.4f;
    float b = 1.6f;

    If you try to compare a and b now, you will get 'false' as an output:

    System.out.println(a == b);

    In order for this comparison to acutally work, you need to round the floats (to 2 decimals in this example):

    System.out.println((Math.round(a * 100f) / 100f) == (Math.round(b * 100f) / 100f));

    This now prints 'bool(true)'


    Note: this might not work on machines whose internal float-size is not 32 bit
    int readInt()
    range: -2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,647

    Space required (in bytes): 4
    long readLong()
    range: -2^63 = -9,223,372,036,854,775,808 to 2^63-1 = 9,223,372,036,854,775,807

    Note: unsigned longs are not supported
    short readShort()
    range: -32,768 to 32,767

    Space required (in bytes): 2
    java.lang.String readStringASCII()
    Supports characters in range 0x0 - 0x7F (Standard US-ASCII without NUL)

    each character uses 7 bits of space

    This implementation uses a space-optimized method of storing ASCII-charcters:
    instead of each character using 1 full byte, each uses only 7 bits
    using this method, you can store 8 characters in 7 bytes or (for instance) 1024 characters in 896 bytes.

    the length of the string is stored as a short (int16) at the beginning of the string.

    Space required (in bytes): 2+âŒˆ0.875*nâŒ‰ or 2+ceil(0.875*n)
    java.lang.String readStringC()
    Supports characters in range 0x1 - 0x7F (Standard US-ASCII without NUL)

    each character uses 1 byte
    unlike DATA_STRING_ASCII, the string length is not stored as a short (int16), but the end of the string is marked with a NUL-byte (like C-strings/ null-terminated strings)

    Space required (in bytes): 1+n
    java.lang.String readStringUTF8()
    Supports characters in range 0x0 - 0xFFFF (Unicode Plane 0/ Basic Multilingual Plane)

    each character uses 1 to 3 bytes of space
    additionally, 2 bytes are used for the length of the string

    Space required (in bytes): 2+n (min) to 2+3*n (max)
    int readUnsignedByte()
    range: 0 to 255

    Space required (in bytes): 1
    long readUnsignedInt()
    range: 0 to 4,294,967,295

    Space required (in bytes): 4
    int readUnsignedShort()
    range: 0 to 65,535

    Space required (in bytes): 2
    int size()

  • Method Details

    • getPacketID

      public int getPacketID()
      Returns:
      the ID of this Packet

    • readBoolean

      public boolean readBoolean()
      in theory a boolean is just a single bit:

      Space required (in bytes): 1
      Returns:
      either 'true' or 'false'

    • readByte

      public byte readByte()
      range: -128 to 127

      Space required (in bytes): 1
      Returns:
      a signed (negative or positive) 8 bit = 1 byte integer (also known as int8)

    • readUnsignedByte

      public int readUnsignedByte()
      range: 0 to 255

      Space required (in bytes): 1
      Returns:
      an unsigned (always positive) 8 bit = 1 byte integer (also known as uint8)

    • readShort

      public short readShort()
      range: -32,768 to 32,767

      Space required (in bytes): 2
      Returns:
      a signed (negative or positive) 16 bit = 2 byte integer (also known as int16)

    • readUnsignedShort

      public int readUnsignedShort()
      range: 0 to 65,535

      Space required (in bytes): 2
      Returns:
      an unsigned (always positive) 16 bit = 2 byte integer (also known as uint16)

    • readInt

      public int readInt()
      range: -2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,647

      Space required (in bytes): 4
      Returns:
      a signed (negative or positive) 32 bit = 4 byte integer (also known as int32)

    • readUnsignedInt

      public long readUnsignedInt()
      range: 0 to 4,294,967,295

      Space required (in bytes): 4
      Returns:
      an unsigned (always positive) 32 bit = 4 byte integer (also known as uint32)

    • readLong

      public long readLong()
      range: -2^63 = -9,223,372,036,854,775,808 to 2^63-1 = 9,223,372,036,854,775,807

      Note: unsigned longs are not supported
      Returns:
      a signed (negative or positive) 64 bit = 4 byte integer (also known as int64)

    • readFloat

      public float readFloat()
      range: (2 - 2^(-23)) * (-2)^127 ≈ -3.403E+38 ≈ 1.401E-45 to (2 - 2^(-23)) * 2^127 ≈ 3.403E+38

      Space required (in bytes): 4

      Note: due to floats being not 100% precise, calculations like 8 - 6.4 are actually not 1.6 as you might except, but 1.5999... You can even try this in Java:

      float a = 8 - 6.4f;
      float b = 1.6f;

      If you try to compare a and b now, you will get 'false' as an output:

      System.out.println(a == b);

      In order for this comparison to acutally work, you need to round the floats (to 2 decimals in this example):

      System.out.println((Math.round(a * 100f) / 100f) == (Math.round(b * 100f) / 100f));

      This now prints 'bool(true)'


      Note: this might not work on machines whose internal float-size is not 32 bit
      Returns:
      a 32 bit = 4 byte single precision floating point number

    • readDouble

      public double readDouble()
      range: (2 - 2^(-52)) * (-2)^1023 ≈ -1.798E+308 to (2 - 2^(-52)) * 2^1023 ≈ 1.798E+308

      Space required (in bytes): 8

      Note: see readFloat() for information about precision
      Note: this might not work on machines whose internal double-size is not 64 bit
      Returns:
      a 64 bit = 8 byte double precision floating point number

    • readStringUTF8

      public java.lang.String readStringUTF8()
      Supports characters in range 0x0 - 0xFFFF (Unicode Plane 0/ Basic Multilingual Plane)

      each character uses 1 to 3 bytes of space
      additionally, 2 bytes are used for the length of the string

      Space required (in bytes): 2+n (min) to 2+3*n (max)
      Returns:
      a UTF-8 encoded string

    • readStringASCII

      public java.lang.String readStringASCII()
      Supports characters in range 0x0 - 0x7F (Standard US-ASCII without NUL)

      each character uses 7 bits of space

      This implementation uses a space-optimized method of storing ASCII-charcters:
      instead of each character using 1 full byte, each uses only 7 bits
      using this method, you can store 8 characters in 7 bytes or (for instance) 1024 characters in 896 bytes.

      the length of the string is stored as a short (int16) at the beginning of the string.

      Space required (in bytes): 2+âŒˆ0.875*nâŒ‰ or 2+ceil(0.875*n)
      Returns:
      an ASCII string

    • readStringC

      public java.lang.String readStringC()
      Supports characters in range 0x1 - 0x7F (Standard US-ASCII without NUL)

      each character uses 1 byte
      unlike DATA_STRING_ASCII, the string length is not stored as a short (int16), but the end of the string is marked with a NUL-byte (like C-strings/ null-terminated strings)

      Space required (in bytes): 1+n
      Returns:
      an ASCII string

    • readByteArray

      public byte[] readByteArray()
      Stores an arbitrary amount of bytes Space required (in bytes): 4+n
      Returns:
      a byte array
